attributes.title: Security Priming, Energy and Exploration: Replication of Luke et al. (2012), Study 2

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Replication of Luke et al. (2012) study 2

sample.value: According to Simonsohn's (2015) 2.5x rule for replication studies, at least 273 participants will be needed. It is aimed to collect data from 300 participants considering the missing cases.

analyses.value: Independent t- tests will be conducted to see the effect of IV on DVs. Additionally, correlation analysis and mediation analysis via Bootsrap method will be conducted to test possible mediator role of energy on exploration.

outliers.value: participants whose Z scores will be higher than +3 or lower than -3 will be excluded. Missing value analysis will be conducted and mutliple imputation or mean replacement technique will be used if the missign values indicate a non-random pattern and if the  missing cases are higher than 5% percent.

dependent.value: Felt Security, Energy and Exploration are key dependent variables. All of the scales were either crated or modified by Luke et al. (2012). We will translate them into Turkish and use for our sample.

conditions.value: There would be two conditions that participants will be assigned into. The secure prime condition is the manipulation condition where the participants are expected to remember a relationship with someone who they feel secure and comforted. We want them to think such a relationship, visualize it and write about that person at least 8 minutes. In the control condition, we want participants to think and visualize a relationship with a someone that they neither like nor dislike, a neutral relationship.

hypothesis.value:
This study is a direct replication of Luke et al. (2012) study 2. The first hypothesis is to observe a higher security ratings among security priming group compared to control group (distant neutral relationship prime condition). Secondly, it is expected that security prime group will have higher ratings of energy and exploration compared to control group. Thirdly, it is expected a positive correlation between feeling security scores and subjective vitality scale scores and exploration index scores. Additionally, it is expected a positive correlation between subjective vitality scores and exploration index scores.
Lastly it is expected that effect of the priming manipulation on exploration will be partly mediated by energy.

attributes.title: Action Effects on Visual Perception of Distances: A Multilevel Bayesian Meta-Analysis
attributes.description:
Some studies suggested that action constraints influence visual perception of distances. For instance, the greater the effort to cover a distance, the longer people perceive this distance. The present multilevel Bayesian meta-analysis supports the existence of a small action constraint effect on distance estimation, Hedge’s g = 0.29, 95% CrI [0.16, 0.47] (Nstudies = 37, Nparticipants = 1035). This effect slightly varied according to the action constraint category (i.e., effort, weight, and tool-use) but not according to participants’ motor intention. Some authors argued such effects reflect experimental demand biases rather than genuine perceptual effects. Our meta-analysis did not allow to dismiss this possibility, but it did not support it. We provide field-specific conventions for interpreting action constraint effect sizes and minimum sample size to detect them with various levels of power. We encourage researchers to update this meta-analysis using our online repository (https://osf.io/bc3wn/) to send their published or unpublished data.

Keywords: perception-action, visual perception, distance perception, meta-analysis, open science

**Please, read the README and the associated FAQ to know how to send the data.**

q1.value: Bee venom acupuncture for adhesive capsulitis: a protocol for  systematic review and meta-analysis

q2.value: Huaying Fan, Xiaohua Chen, Jiao Chen, Huayu Fan, Ping Wu

q3.value: Bee venom acupuncture has been used in treating patients with shoulder adhesive capsulitis, yet the effectiveness and safety remains unclear. Therefore, this systematic review will aim to assess the effectiveness and safety of bee venom acupuncture for shoulder adhesive capsulitis.

q4.value:
Shoulder adhesive capsulitis, also known as frozen shoulder, is a common shoulder condition caused by injury or degeneration of the shoulder joint and articular capsule. The condition is characterized by pain, stiffness, and dysfunction of the affected shoulder. The prevalence of shoulder adhesive capsulitis is about 2% to 5% in general adult population and 10% to 20% in diabetics of the general population. The majority of patients diagnosed with adhesive capsulitis are women between 40 and 60 years of age. Patients with shoulder adhesive capsulitis are more likely to experience sleepless, anxiety, and even disability, which may seriously affect the patients’ daily life and occupational activities. As a self-limited disease, shoulder adhesive capsulitis can persist for years with some patients never regaining full function of their shoulder, which may account for an enormous economic pressure on healthcare.  In the UK, for example, the National Health Service (NHS) costs at least £44.1 million to £110.3 million based on a single general practitioner consultation for each case. Currently, the treatments of shoulder adhesive capsulitis include cortisone injections, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), physiotherapy, arthroscopic capsular release and manipulation under anesthesia, etc. However, most of the treatments only have some effective therapy in a short-term, and the majority of these interventions are often accompanied by varying degrees of side-effects. 
     Bee venom acupuncture is a form of acupuncture in which bee venom is applied to the tips of acupuncture needles, stingers are extracted from bees, or bees are held with an instrument, such as a forceps, squeezed to cause the stinger to emerge from the lower abdomen, and then either the needles or stinger is applied acupoints on the skin. Bee venom acupuncture has been widely used as a complementary and alternative therapy to relieve pain and inflammation for 3000 years. Studies have demonstrated that bee venom acupuncture contains many kinds of components which may show pharmacological actions such as anti-inflammation, anti-apoptosis, anti-fibrosis and anti-arthrosclerosis. With these pharmaceutical characteristics, bee venom acupuncture has been used as the therapeutic method in treating osteoarthritis keen pain, Parkinson’s disease,  rheumatoid arthritis,  etc. Moreover, studies have indicated that bee venom acupuncture with physical therapy can be more effective in improving pain and function than physical therapy alone, and may help to improve long-term of life in patients with shoulder adhesive capsulitis. 
Although bee venom acupuncture has been utilized to treat shoulder adhesive capsulitis for a long time, there was no systematic review conducted to assess the effectiveness and safety of bee venom acupuncture for shoulder adhesive capsulitis. Therefore, we conducted this systematic review to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of bee venom acupuncture for shoulder adhesive capsulitis.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
1. Study design. All randomized controlled trials (RCTs) involving bee venom acupuncture for treating shoulder adhesive capsulitis will be included without restriction on language or publication type. Studies with non-RCT design, quasi-experiment design, unobtainable data, duplicate publications, animal experiments and reviews or case reports will be excluded.
2.Participants. Adult participants (≥ 18 years old) presenting with shoulder adhesive capsulitis will be included regardless of sex, race, or educational and economic status. Participants with severe physical or mental disease will be excluded. 
3. Interventions and comparators. Interventions in the treatment group will include bee venom acupuncture. Comparators will include physiotherapy, placebo control, no treatment/waiting list control, or active treatment (e.g. nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and/or local injection of corticosteroids, etc.) will be included. RCTs evaluating bee venom acupuncture combined with another treatment compared with that other treatment alone will also be included. 
4. Outcomes. Primary outcome will be the pain visual analogue scale (VAS). Secondary outcomes will include active and passive range of motions (ROMs), shoulder pain and disability index (SPADI). Besides, safety measurement and adverse events will also be considered.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Two reviewers (HYF and XHC) will respectively screen the study titles and abstracts to identify potentially eligible studies according to the inclusion criteria. The full texts reviews will be obtained and independently screened before final inclusion. Two reviewers (JC and HYF) will independently extract the data of all eligible studies by employing a standard pre-designed form. The following items will be included in the data extraction form: first author, year of publication, country, number of centers and the participants, study design, number of groups, interventions, comparisons, outcomes (primary and second outcomes) and conclusions. The final extracted data will be cross-checked and any disagreement regarding to the extracted data will be discussed and adjudicated by a third reviewer (PW). If any data are insufficient or unclear, the first or corresponding author for the study concerned will be contacted via e-mail or telephone to provide additional information.

q13.value: As this is a systematic review, no sample size is needed.

question.value: Primary outcome will be the pain visual analogue scale (VAS). Secondary outcomes will include active and passive range of motions (ROMs), shoulder pain and disability index (SPADI). Besides, safety measurement and adverse events will also be considered.

Meta-analysis will be done by using Review Manager software (V.5.3). Mean difference (MD) with 95% confidence intervals will be used for continuous data and risk ratios (RRs) will be used for dichotomous data. Random effect model will be selected in data pooling. Heterogeneity will be assessed by chi-square and I2 test. If heterogeneity is found (I2> 50%), we will try to explain the clinical and methodological diversity or conduct subgroup analysis. However, if we cannot determine the reason for heterogeneity, we will conduct a descriptive analysis instead of a meta-analysis.

q23.value: Missing data will obtain by contacting authors.

q25.value: Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation (GRADE), which is a method of grading the level of evidence and is developed by the GRADE Working Group, will be applied to evaluate the quality of evidence by two independent reviewers (HYF and HYF). The GRADEpro software (version 3.6 for Windows, Grade Working Group) will be utilized.

attributes.title: Effects of Mood on Memory and the Empathy-Gap

q1.value: Effects of Mood on Memory and the Empathy-Gap

q3.value: This study is a one-way between-subjects experiment, which will evaluate the effect of a happy or sad mood on both memory and the hot-cold empathy gap. Participants will be randomly assigned into either a happy or sad condition, and will all watch a movie clip. Participants will then be evaluated on their level of empathy for the character in the movie clip, their memory of the video, and how much pain they believe the character in the story was in.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: Writing a sad or upsetting personal event for five minutes will cause participants to have a more negative/ sad mood than those who wrote about a positive or happy personal event for five minutes. 
Hypotheses 2: Participants in an induced sad mood will empathize more with the character in the movie clip than those who were assigned to the happy condition. 
 Hypothesis 3: Participants in an induced sad mood will rate the person in the movie clip's situation as more painful than those who are currently happy.
 Hypothesis 4: Participants in an induced sad mood will recall details about the movie clip more accurately than those who were assigned to the happy condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study is a one-way between-subjects experiment

q9.value: There are only two levels to the independent variable (happy vs. sad). Handouts asking people to write on happy or sad topics will be shuffled into the same stack and will be handed out at random to the participants when it is time to manipulate the independent variable.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The data have been entered into a jamovi data set.

question.value: Participants will all be students from Olivet Nazarene University, and they were recruited on campus using a physical sign-up sheet. Three classes of students were given the opportunity to sign up for the experiment, and those who participate will be given extra-credit as compensation. They were able to choose from three sessions. Before the study began, participants were instructed to read and sign the informed consent form provided if they wished to continue, before they started the experiment. This form outlined the nature and purpose of the experiment, included a brief explanation of the procedures, benefits and risks of the study, and information regarding their privacy. The form also informed them that their participation is always voluntary, and that they may withdraw at any point during the experiment. Contact information for myself, Dr. Veit, and the ONU IRB and Counseling Services were provided at the end of the form. This form, along with all other scales, questionnaires, and documents, were given in hard copy. Students who wished to continue and participate in the study then handed in their signed informed consent form. The first procedure of the experiment participants received was the Brief Mood Introspection Scale (Mayer & Gaschke, 2013) in order to get a baseline measurement of their mood at the beginning of the study. They then filled out the prosocialness scale for adults (Caprara, Steca, Zelli, & Capanna, 2005), which helped to control for their baseline level of prosocial tendencies. Next they completed the 18-Item Need for Cognition Scale (Cacioppo, 1983), which was used to get a baseline measurement for each participants’ need for cognition. After all participants in the classroom had finished filling out the first three scales, I handed out the papers on which they will write either a happy or sad personal story. Half of the papers instructed participants to write a sad personal event, and the other half instructed them to write about a positive personal event. After all the papers had been handed out, I started a timer for five minutes and instructed the participants to begin writing for the entire duration of the five minutes. After the five minutes of writing, I collected their short stories and scales and handed out the next set of questions for them to fill out later. After each participant had been given the next set of questionnaires, I played a short movie clip from the movie The Champ for all participants to watch before filling out the scales. After watching the video, participants completed the Faces Pain Scale-Revised (Nordgren, McDonnel, & Loewenstein, 2011) to measure their mood and ensure the manipulation was effective. They then filled out the last three scales they received in the handout.  The first of these scales was the Self-Overlap Scale (Aron, Aron, & Smollan, 1992), followed by the Shen’s State Empathy Scale (Shen, 2010), which will both be used to measure the extent to which they identified and empathized with the character. Then, participants rated on a scale from one to ten how painful the situation in the video was for the little boy. After completing these scales, all participants answered the attached list of ten questions to measure their memory of the video. Lastly, participants were asked five questions regarding their sex, age, ethnicity, and year in school, which were also included in the handout. After handing in the last packet of scales and questions, they were then be given the opportunity to have a debriefing session with me. During this session I fully explained the purpose of the study. Before they signed out, all participants were given a debriefing document on which they wrote out five things that they are thankful for in order to ease those in the sad condition into a more positive mood. This document also thanked them for their participation, outlined the purpose of the study, and included the contact information for Dr. Veit, the ONU Institutional Review Board, and Olivet’s Counseling Services, and for myself. At the end of the debriefing session, I asked each student to write their name, email and which class they wished to receive extra credit for on a separate form.

q13.value: I was able to recruit 50 participants.

question.value: I manipulated the participants' mood by randomly assigning them to either a happy or sad condition. Participants in the sad condition wrote for five minutes about a sad or upsetting personal event and participants in the happy condition wrote for five minutes about a happy or positive personal event.

Mood: Mood will be evaluated before and after the IV manipulation to see if it was effective in creating a sad mood. 
Empathy: Empathy will be evaluated to tell how much empathy each participant had towards the little boy in the video. A baseline of their prosocial behavior will also be evaluated. 
Pain: I will ask each participant to rate on a scale from one to ten how painful the situation in the video was for the little boy. 
Memory: Memory will evaluated by asking participants 10 questions relating to the movie clip.
Baseline need for cognition: In order to control for the confounding variable of the participants’ memory of the movie clip that is not based on their congruency of mood with the character or empathy with the character in the movie clip, I will get a baseline of their need for cognition before they answer the 10 questions about the movie clip.

Mood will be measured by using the Faces-Pain Scale-Revised (Nordgren, McDonnel, & Loewenstein, 2011), which gives participants six choices of faces on a scale of 0 to 10 from a neutral to negative mood. I will also get a baseline of their mood at the beginning of the study using the Brief Mood Introspection Scale, which has 16 moods that participants rate on a continuum from 1 to 4 using the following criteria: (definitely do not feel) (do not feel) (slightly feel) (definitely feel), followed by a scale from -10 to 10 from a very unpleasant mood to a pleasant mood (Mayer & Gaschke, 2013). Empathy will be measured using the Self-Overlap Scale, which has them choose between seven pictures depicting how much they empathize with the boy in the movie clip (Aron, Aron, & Smollan, 1992). This will be followed by the Shen’s State Empathy Scale, which includes a list of 12 items on a scale of 0 to for with 0 being “not at all” and 4 being “completely” (Shen, 2010). I will also get a baseline of their empathy and prosocial behavior tendencies using the prosocialness scale for adults, which has 16 items and participants will check off any of them that apply to them (Caprara, Steca, Zelli, & Capanna, 2005). To measure how much pain they thought the boy in the clip was in I will ask each participant to rate on a scale from one to ten how painful the situation in the video was for the little boy. I will measure their memory by asking them ten questions relating to the movie clip. In order to control for the memory of the movie clip that was not based on their emotional congruency or empathy with the character I will get a baseline of their need for cognition using the 18-Item Need for Cognition Scale (Cacioppo, 1983).

Hypothesis 1: one way between-subjects ANOVA
Hypothesis 2: ANCOVA 
Hypothesis 3: ANCOVA 
Hypothesis 4: ANCOVA

q20.value: I will not transform any of the data. Certain items from the 18-Item Need for Cognition Scale (Cacioppo, 1983) and the Brief Mood Introspection Scale (Mayer & Gaschke, 2013) will need to be re-coded during data analysis.

q21.value:
p<.05 will be the standard for statistical significance. 
Cronbach’s alpha will help to measure internal consistency.
The Bronferroni correction will be used to protect against the familywise error rate.

q22.value: I will run my analyses both with and without outliers. A participant who has a z score of +/- 3 on any variable will be considered an outlier.

q23.value: If a participant has missing data on more than one scale or on any other section they will be excluded from the study. If a participant has missing data on only one scale or section, then they will be excluded from analyses involving those variables.

q24.value: I will investigate relationships between demographic information (age, gender, ethnicity, and class in school) and mood, empathy, rating of pain, and memory.

After each participant had been given the next set of questionnaires, I played a short movie clip from the movie The Champ for all participants to watch before filling out the scales. After watching the video, participants completed the Faces Pain Scale-Revised (Nordgren, McDonnel, & Loewenstein, 2011) to measure their mood and ensure the manipulation was effective. They then filled out the last three scales they received in the handout.  The first of these scales was the Self-Overlap Scale (Aron, Aron, & Smollan, 1992), followed by the Shen’s State Empathy Scale (Shen, 2010), which will both be used to measure the extent to which they identified and empathized with the character. Then, participants rated on a scale from one to ten how painful the situation in the video was for the little boy. After completing these scales, all participants answered the attached list of ten questions to measure their memory of the video. Lastly, participants were asked five questions regarding their sex, age, ethnicity, and year in school, which were also included in the handout. After handing in the last packet of scales and questions, they were then be given the opportunity to have a debriefing session with me. During this session I fully explained the purpose of the study. Before they signed out, all participants were given a debriefing document on which they wrote out five things that they are thankful for in order to ease those in the sad condition into a more positive mood. This document also thanked them for their participation, outlined the purpose of the study, and included the contact information for Dr. Veit, the ONU Institutional Review Board, and Olivet’s Counseling Services, and for myself. At the end of the debriefing session, I asked each student to write their name, email and which class they wished to receive extra credit for on a separate form.
registration_responses.q16.question: I manipulated the participants' mood by randomly assigning them to either a happy or sad condition. Participants in the sad condition wrote for five minutes about a sad or upsetting personal event and participants in the happy condition wrote for five minutes about a happy or positive personal event.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Mood: Mood will be evaluated before and after the IV manipulation to see if it was effective in creating a sad mood. 
Empathy: Empathy will be evaluated to tell how much empathy each participant had towards the little boy in the video. A baseline of their prosocial behavior will also be evaluated. 
Pain: I will ask each participant to rate on a scale from one to ten how painful the situation in the video was for the little boy. 
Memory: Memory will evaluated by asking participants 10 questions relating to the movie clip.
Baseline need for cognition: In order to control for the confounding variable of the participants’ memory of the movie clip that is not based on their congruency of mood with the character or empathy with the character in the movie clip, I will get a baseline of their need for cognition before they answer the 10 questions about the movie clip.
registration_responses.q18.question: Mood will be measured by using the Faces-Pain Scale-Revised (Nordgren, McDonnel, & Loewenstein, 2011), which gives participants six choices of faces on a scale of 0 to 10 from a neutral to negative mood. I will also get a baseline of their mood at the beginning of the study using the Brief Mood Introspection Scale, which has 16 moods that participants rate on a continuum from 1 to 4 using the following criteria: (definitely do not feel) (do not feel) (slightly feel) (definitely feel), followed by a scale from -10 to 10 from a very unpleasant mood to a pleasant mood (Mayer & Gaschke, 2013). Empathy will be measured using the Self-Overlap Scale, which has them choose between seven pictures depicting how much they empathize with the boy in the movie clip (Aron, Aron, & Smollan, 1992). This will be followed by the Shen’s State Empathy Scale, which includes a list of 12 items on a scale of 0 to for with 0 being “not at all” and 4 being “completely” (Shen, 2010). I will also get a baseline of their empathy and prosocial behavior tendencies using the prosocialness scale for adults, which has 16 items and participants will check off any of them that apply to them (Caprara, Steca, Zelli, & Capanna, 2005). To measure how much pain they thought the boy in the clip was in I will ask each participant to rate on a scale from one to ten how painful the situation in the video was for the little boy. I will measure their memory by asking them ten questions relating to the movie clip. In order to control for the memory of the movie clip that was not based on their emotional congruency or empathy with the character I will get a baseline of their need for cognition using the 18-Item Need for Cognition Scale (Cacioppo, 1983).

other.value:
Secondary analysis:
QUESTIONNAIRE ANALYSES 
(i) Logistic regression will be used to investigate outcome: recall of inserted word (1 vs. 0) as a function of predictor: recognition strategy (continuum: 1 [offloading] to 5 [internal]) on block 5 (inserted item second time).

(ii) Linear regression will be used to investigate outcome: confidence in the inserted word (1 to 4) as a function of predictor: recognition strategy (continuum: 1 [offloading] to 5 [internal]) on block 5 (inserted item second time).

(iii) Two logistic regression analyses will be used to investigate:
-Relations between predictor of question 2 response (recognition strategy: 1 [offloading] to 5 [internal]) and the outcome of question 3 response (yes/no to word being inserted: 1 vs. 0).
-Relations between predictor of question 2 response (recognition strategy: 1 [offloading] to 5 [internal]) and the outcome of  question 4 response (identifying inserted word: 1 vs. 0) each.

sample.value: The sample size is n=70, which is twice that of a previous study pre-registered at https://osf.io/zpuaj/

analyses.value:
Means of all DVs (Recall, Confidence, Endorsement, Question answers 1-4) will be calculated and reported across the various conditions. 

INSERTED ITEM 
(i) McNemar’s test will be used to analyze the effect of IV inserted item condition (first insertion vs. second insertion) on DV recall for the inserted item. 
(ii) Welch paired sample t-test will be used to analyze the effect of IV inserted item condition (first insertion vs. second insertion) on DV confidence rating for the inserted item. Provided confidence analyzes require participants to have recalled the item, these analyses will only be conducted if there is a sufficient number of participants (16).

ITEM IMMEDIATELY BEFORE THE INSERTED ITEM (CONTROL ITEM)
(i) McNemar’s test will be used to analyze the effect of IV inserted item condition (first insertion vs. second insertion) on DV recall for the item immediately before the inserted item. 
(ii) Welch paired sample t-test will be used to analyze the effect of IV inserted item condition (first insertion vs. second insertion) on DV confidence rating for the item immediately before the inserted item. Provided confidence analyzes require participants to have recalled the item, these analyses will only be conducted if there is a sufficient number of participants (16).

INSERTED ITEM VS. ITEM IMMEDIATELY BEFORE THE INSERTED ITEM 
(i) McNemar's test will be used to analyze the effect of IV Item type (inserted vs. item before) on DV recall separately for the first insertion and second insertion blocks. 
(ii) Welch paired sample t-test will be used to analyze the effect of IV Item type (inserted vs. item before) on DV confidence rating separately for the first insertion and second insertion blocks. Provided confidence analyzes require participants to have recalled the item, these analyses will only be conducted if there is a sufficient number of participants (16). 

Two follow-up mixed effects regression analyses:
iii) Mixed effects regression analyses with recall (logistic) as the DV.  IVs insertion condition (Trial 4 vs. Trial 5), Item type (inserted vs. one or more targets before), and their interaction will be included as fixed factors with participant as a random effect. 
*Note* the mixed effects logistic regression analysis cannot be done in the case that an item is completely recalled/not recalled by all participants on at least one of the trials (Trial 4 and/or Trial 5). 

iv) Mixed effects regression analyses with confidence (gaussian) as the DV.  IVs insertion condition (Trial 4 vs. Trial 5), Item type (inserted vs. one or more targets before), and their interaction will be included as fixed factors with participant as a random effect. 
*Note* Confidence analyses will only be conducted if there are a sufficient number of participants (16).

outliers.value:
Data exclusions: 
All written words during the encoding phase will be used in calculating descriptive measures for non-inserted words (e.g. endorsement and confidence) in the recall phase. If a participant does not type a word into their external store during the encoding phase, then the answers given for those specific unwritten words in the recall phase (e.g. endorsement and confidence) will not be included in the analyses or descriptive measures.

If participants did not write down the word before the inserted item in their external store, then the item before the item before will be used as a control for analysis that includes the word before the inserted item. If a participant did not write down the word before the inserted item and the word before that, then they will be excluded from all analyses (including descriptives).

If participants recall the control item or inserted item but forget to give a confidence rating, then that participant will be excluded (since our DVs are looking at the confidence of that recalled item, but we are not able to infer it). 

If participants recall the control item or inserted item with a confidence of 1 or 2 (against instruction of only writing words with a confidence of 3 or 4 and not writing ones they would give a confidence of 1 or 2), then that item will not be considered to be recalled and thus, not have an associated confidence rating. Consequently, these items will not be included in the confidence rating analysis.

dependent.value:
1. Recall from 0 (not recalled) to 1 (recalled) for each word during recall trials. Of particular interest are the recall sores for inserted items vs non-inserted items. 

2. Confidence as continuous ratings from 1 to 4: (1: "definitely not presented originally" vs. 2: "probably not presented..." vs. 3: "probably presented..." vs. 4: "definitely presented...") is presented as an option for each word during recall trials, however by instruction, options 3 and 4 should only be chosen since participants are to only recall words that they remember were presented to them. 

3. After the first block in which a word is inserted into the ​participant's external memory store (block 4) participants are asked: "We inserted '(inserted word specified)', did you notice? Please respond with 'y' for yes or 'n' for no”. This question will be coded as yes vs. no (coded as binary 1 and 0 respectively).

4. After the final block (block 5), participants will be asked a series of questions:
(strategy)  "Please select the option that best describes your recognition strategy during the final (fifth) block of this study (a) I relied exclusively on my typed list during the recognition task (b) I relied mostly on my typed list during the recognition task (c) I relied about equally on both my list and my internal memory during the recognition task (d) I relied mostly on my internal memory during the recognition task (e) I relied exclusively on my internal memory during the recognition task (z) None of the above" This question will be coded using "a" = 1, "b" = 2, "c" = 3, etc., however, participants answering "z" will not be included in the analyses of this question and simply serves as a means to identify participants not using our expected memory strategies. 

(block 5 believe that  a word was inserted) "On the last block we may have added a word to your typed list that was not presented originally, please respond with 'y' for yes or 'n' for no as to whether you believe we inserted a word into your list on your final block." This question will be coded as yes vs. no (coded as binary 1 and 0 respectively).

(block 5 select word) "Please review your list from the last block and type one word that you most think was added. Even if you don’t think something was added, please guess." This question will be coded as inserted word specified vs. inserted word not specified (coded as 1 and 0 respectively).

conditions.value:
This is a within-subjects experiment where on the fourth and fifth block, a word is inserted into the participant’s typed list unbeknownst to them. 
Within conditions:
IV inserted item condition (first insertion vs. second insertion)
IV Item type (inserted vs. item before (control))

hypothesis.value: Previous work showed that when a list of to-be-remembered words are offloaded into a computer file and a word is inserted (without the participant's knowledge) into that list, participants endorsed and were highly confident that the inserted word had been presented originally (Risko, Kelly, Patel & Gaspar, 2019). We extend this notion by investigating how the perceived reliability of the external store influences this effect. That is, if the participant is made aware that their list has been tampered with on one block, will participants alter their behaviour on the following block such that participants will demonstrate more sensitivity to the manipulation of their external store?

attributes.title: Covid-19 WHO vs. Social media recommendations

q2.value: Jingshi Liu, Anirban Mukhopadhyay, Catherine Wing-man Yeung

q3.value:
In this study, we want to understand what influence people's anxiety during the Covid-19 outbreak. Specifically, we will measure what people know about the precaution recommendations provided by WHO vs. the social media, what precautions they are taking, how anxious and vital they feel during this time period, their stockpiling behaviors, and their prediction of the virus outbreak outcome. We will manipulate the source of information they receive and test how that may affect their anxiety level. We will also measure some individual differences, such as trust in since and social comparison orientation. 

The data will be collected in Hong Kong, Singapore, and the U.S. We are collecting data in the second week of March, 2020, when the Covid-19 has infected over 105 thousand people in 101 countries, areas or territories.

q4.value:
1. The extent to which people can correctly identify WHO recommendations may correlate with their anxiety. 
2. The number of precautions that people are taking may correlate with their anxiety level. 
3. Our recommendation source manipulation – whether people receive recommendations from the WHO or recommendations from the social media – may affect their anxiety level. 
4. The effect of recommendation source on anxiety may be moderated by people’s knowledge accuracy about WHO recommended precautions. 
5. The above effects may also affect vitality. 
6. Anxiety may correlate with vitality level, stockpiling behavior, predictions of the outbreak outcome, trust in WHO/government/other people/social media, and worries about mask usage and knowledge about masks.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study has a 2 (recommendation source: WHO, social media; between-subjects) X precaution knowledge (measured) X 3 countries design.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two recommendation source conditions. The number of participants in each condition will be balanced.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The study will be distributed by Qualtrics Panel in Hong Kong, Singapore, and the U.S. We will collect data from 1000 participants in each region. The sample should be nationally representative on age and gender for each region. Data collection will take place at the same time in all three regions, and is estimated to take 5-10 days to complete. The survey to be distributed in Singapore and the U.S. is in English, and the survey to be distributed in Hong Kong is translated to Chinese. 

Participants are recruited from the Qualtrics panel. They must be residents of Hong Kong, Singapore, or the U.S. to participate in the study. They must pass a Qualtrics Captcha before starting the survey.

q13.value: 1000 participants per region, 3000 participants in total.

q15.value: Data collection will stop once the sample size is reached.

question.value:
After participants indicated which Covid-19 precautions are recommended as most important by medical professionals and which ones they practice themselves, they will be assigned to one of the two recommendation source conditions. They will see one of the following: 

A. 
As we mentioned earlier, the 8 recommendations are gathered from different sources. The 4 listed below are provided by the WHO (World Health Organization) and are recommended by medial professionals worldwide. 
-          Wash your hands frequently
-          Maintain social distancing
-          Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth
-          Practice respiratory hygiene

OR B. 
As we mentioned earlier, the 8 recommendations are gathered from different sources. The 4 listed below are gathered from social media sources and are widely shared by many people. 
-           Do a deep-breath self-check every morning to achieve early diagnosis of infection
-           Drink water and keep your throat moist
-           Wear a face mask whenever you go out
-           Disinfect items you bring back home, including your phone, computer, jackets, and everything you buy from outside. Either spray alcohol on them or wipe with diluted bleach
Please find the attached file for all the measured variables.

An index of recommendation knowledge accuracy will be created by the number of correct WHO recommendations selected (ranged from 0-4). 
The precaution behavior measure will be the number of (WHO or social media recommended) precautions taken. 
The stockpiling measure will total number of product categories that one is stockpiling. 
All the established scale measures will be reversed coded (if necessary, based on the original scale development) and averaged to create the indexes.

1)	Descriptive analyses for each region (Hong Kong, Singapore, the U.S.): 
•	The accuracy of identifying precautions recommended by medical professionals 
•	What precautions that people are taking, which are recommended by WHO vs. social media, and how it is broken down by people’s knowledge accuracy. 
•	People’s anxiety level and subjective vitality level 
•	People’s predictions of the outcome of the virus breakdown 
•	People’s trust of WHO, government, other people, and social media 
•	Stockpiling behaviors, worries about mask usage, knowledge about the surgical mask, and personal contact with people who are infected by Covid-19 
•	The first word that comes to people’s mind when thinking about Covid-19. 
2)	Correlational analyses:
•	Test the relationships between knowledge accuracy of recommended precautions, precaution behaviors, outcome predictions, trust, stockpiling behaviors, worries about masks, knowledge of face masks, and anxiety and vitality. 
3)	ANOVAs and regressions: 
•	Test the effect of recommendation source manipulation on anxiety, vitality, and outcome predictions. 
•	Test whether the above effects are moderated by knowledge accuracy of recommended precautions, and precaution behaviors. 
•	Repeat the above analyses with personal medical background, social media usage, and demographic information as covariates.

q20.value: Reversed coded items in established scales will be reversed coded based on the guideline of the published scale development.

q21.value: p less than or equal to .1 is marginally significant, p less than or equal to .05 is significant.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if 1) they failed the attention check (embedded in the trust in science scale measure) or 2) they wrote non-sense responses in any of the open-ended questions.

q23.value: All questions are "force response". Data from participants who did not complete all the questions will not be analyzed.

q24.value:
4)	Test the correlations between personal medical background, social media usage, demographic information, trust in science, social comparison orientation, and anxiety and vitality. 
5)	Test the potential moderating effects of trust, stockpiling behaviors, worries about masks, knowledge of face masks, personal medical background, social media usage, individual difference in trust in science, individual difference in social comparison, and demographic information.

-          Practice respiratory hygiene

OR B. 
As we mentioned earlier, the 8 recommendations are gathered from different sources. The 4 listed below are gathered from social media sources and are widely shared by many people. 
-           Do a deep-breath self-check every morning to achieve early diagnosis of infection
-           Drink water and keep your throat moist
-           Wear a face mask whenever you go out
-           Disinfect items you bring back home, including your phone, computer, jackets, and everything you buy from outside. Either spray alcohol on them or wipe with diluted bleach

An index of recommendation knowledge accuracy will be created by the number of correct WHO recommendations selected (ranged from 0-4). 
The precaution behavior measure will be the number of (WHO or social media recommended) precautions taken.

registration_responses.q19.question:
1)	Descriptive analyses for each region (Hong Kong, Singapore, the U.S.):

•	People’s anxiety level and subjective vitality level 
•	People’s predictions of the outcome of the virus breakdown 
•	People’s trust of WHO, government, other people, and social media 
•	Stockpiling behaviors, worries about mask usage, knowledge about the surgical mask, and personal contact with people who are infected by Covid-19 
•	The first word that comes to people’s mind when thinking about Covid-19. 
2)	Correlational analyses:
•	Test the relationships between knowledge accuracy of recommended precautions, precaution behaviors, outcome predictions, trust, stockpiling behaviors, worries about masks, knowledge of face masks, and anxiety and vitality. 
3)	ANOVAs and regressions: 
•	Test the effect of recommendation source manipulation on anxiety, vitality, and outcome predictions. 
•	Test whether the above effects are moderated by knowledge accuracy of recommended precautions, and precaution behaviors. 
•	Repeat the above analyses with personal medical background, social media usage, and demographic information as covariates.

attributes.title: Inhibitory Control in ADHD: A Meta-analysis of Oculomotor Measures

summary.value:
PRISMA-P PROTOCOL
------
SECTION 1: Identification

“Inhibitory Control in ADHD: Protocol for a Meta-analysis of Oculomotor Measures”
(New protocol, March 2020)

2. Registration: Open Science Framework
Author contributions:
YC: conception of the idea and design of the protocol, establishment of selection criteria,
implementation of search strategy and selection of studies.
LB: support to design the protocol, providing statistical expertise to determine the plan for data analyses, synthesis, and interpretation.
JK: support to design the protocol, providing statistical expertise to determine the plan for data analyses, synthesis, and interpretation.
SS: contribution to search strategy, double-check for the selection process.
UE: conception of the idea and design of the protocol, establishment of selection criteria, supervision
of search strategy and selection of the studies.
All contributors read, provided feedback and approved the protocol.

Amendments: NA.
Support:  Scholarship for Postdoctoral Stays Abroad awarded to YC.

SECTION 2: Introduction

6. Rationale
Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder
characterized by unusual levels of inattention, impulsivity and hyperactivity (American Psychiatric Association, 2013). Given the large variability in the expression of this disorder, an extensive search for biological markers of the disorder has been conducted, looking for those characteristics that allow to distinguish clinical cases from the general population and to deepen the knowledge about the physiology of the disorder.
Among the different techniques used to identify biological markers in psychiatric disorders,
eye- tracking methodologies and the study of eye movements provides a powerful research tool to assess working functions of the brain and processes related to the flexible control of behavior such as decision making and task switching (Pouget, 2019). Since we can fixate on only one visual target at any one time, we are constantly selecting among different alternatives upon which to focus (Milea et al., 2007), resisting distractor stimuli and overriding predominant responses that are incompatible with the goal we have in mind (Polner et al., 2015; Roberts et al., 2011). This ability to withhold actions to refrain from acting reflexively, habitually or impulsively (Bompas et al., 2019), and to minimize the
processing of irrelevant information while selecting relevant information (Ettinger et al., 2018) is identified as inhibition and is one of the fundamental components of the executive control of behavior (Bari & Robbins, 2013; Miyake et al., 2000).
Deficits in inhibitory control have been proposed as one of the main characteristics of ADHD
(Barkley, 1997; Wodka et al., 2007). Evidence of differences between cases and typical population when executing tasks such as the go/no-go (Epstein et al., 2007; Uebel et al., 2010; Wiersema & Roeyers, 2009) and stop-signal tasks (Alderson et al., 2008; Schachar et al., 2007; Tillman et al., 2008) supports this hypothesis. Oculomotor tasks, however, provide the advantage of assessing motor responses that are reflex-like in nature and do not have to be trained (Roberts et al., 2011). There is an increasing number of studies where the inhibition of unwanted responses is assessed in ADHD using paradigms such as the antisaccade task, the countermanding saccadic task, the oculomotor capture task, and the memory-guided saccade task, among others (see Table 1 in Appendix A for detailed information). In addition, prosaccade, fixational control, and smooth pursuit tasks are frequently used to measure processes of visual attention, basic sensorimotor transformations, and other visuomotor
functions (see Table 2 in Appendix A). To summarize and quantify the effects reported in the
oculomotor outcome measures across different tasks of eye movements will provide useful
information about the sensitivity of these tasks as tools to assess inhibitory impairments in ADHD.

Key Questions:
On the basis of these findings, we formulate the following research questions:
- Primary Research Question and Hypothesis: ADHD patients have impaired oculomotor
inhibitory control compared to healthy individuals.
- Exploratory Research Question 1: What are the effects of potential moderators such as age,
sex and medication status?
- Exploratory Research Question 2: Which of the employed oculomotor inhibitory control
outcomes show the greatest sensitivity to ADHD?
- Exploratory Research Question 3: Are there other, non-inhibitory oculomotor deficits in
ADHD, involving temporal or spatial aspects of eye movements? How do these effect sizes
compare to those of our Primary Research Question?
- Exploratory Research Question 4: How do the effect sizes from Research Question 1
qualitatively compare to effect sizes of other inhibitory tasks from published meta-analyses,
e.g. of the stop-signal, go/no-go, Eriksen flanker and Stroop tasks?

7. Objectives
To summarize the effects reported in studies that compared the inhibition of oculomotor
responses between ADHD patients and non-clinical controls (children, adolescents, and adults). No intervention effects will be studied; however, we will consider medication status of ADHD participants as potential moderator, if sufficient data are available (ON/OFF, medication type, and dose). The analyses will focus on case-control comparisons; age, sex and medication status will be included as moderators. The primary outcomes will be the measures related to the inhibition of oculomotor responses in different tasks (Table 1). We will analyze additional measures related to temporal and spatial aspects of eye movements as secondary outcomes (Table 2).
This meta-analysis will be conducted following PRISMA-P (2015) guidelines (Shamseer et
al., 2015) and will be pre-registered at Open Science Framework (OSF) before data extraction.

SECTION 3: Methods

8. Eligibility criteria
The search phase was last updated in February 2020. We searched for studies assessing eye
movements in individuals with ADHD. Figure 1 (Appendix A) depicts the search flow and the criteria used for the review.

9. Information sources
Electronic database search was conducted in PubMed (https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/) and Web of Science (www.webofknowledge.com). Detailed information is found in Table 3 (Appendix A). No data extraction was done during pre-registration. We also scanned the reference lists of relevant reviews identified through the search to ensure literature saturation. We searched for supplementary files to make sure that all relevant material has been identified.

10. Search strategy 
We used terms related to “eye movements” or “eye tracking”, combined with “ADHD” or
“Attention Deficit with Hyperactivity Disorder”. General inhibitory control-related terms (not
involving eye movements) were not included in the search to be able to detect relevant findings in ADHD studies that are not explicitly assessing inhibitory control but might include oculomotor measures related with this domain (e.g. anticipatory responses, number of deviations from a given target).
The PubMed search strategy was: (oculomotor OR "ocular motor" OR "eye movement" OR
"eye movements" OR saccade OR saccades OR saccadic OR antisaccade OR antisaccades OR
antisaccadic OR countermanding OR "smooth pursuit" OR "smooth eye" OR "pursuit eye" OR "eye tracking" OR eyetracking OR eyetracker OR eye-tracker) AND (adhd OR "attention deficit
hyperactivity disorder").
After PubMed search, we adapted the terms to the syntax of Web of Science as follows:
TOPIC: ((oculomotor OR "ocular motor" OR "eye movement" OR "eye movements" OR saccade OR saccades OR saccadic OR antisaccade OR antisaccades OR antisaccadic OR countermanding OR "smooth pursuit" OR "smooth eye" OR "pursuit eye" OR "eye tracking" OR eyetracking OR eyetracker OR eye-tracker) AND (adhd OR "attention deficit hyperactivity disorder")).
The results retrieved in each search were double-checked by a second researcher (UE). The
search strategy completed until this point is depicted in the flow diagram in Figure 1.

11. Study records
11a. Mechanism(s) used to manage records and data throughout the review: We have
adapted Excel templates reported elsewhere (Moreau & Gamble, 2020) to manage records obtained from the literature search.

11b. Process for selecting studies: YC conducted the first screening by reviewing the titles
and abstracts yielded by the search (abstract screening). A score ranging from 0 to 2 was assigned to each record as follows: 0=unsuitable (no ADHD sample, or no oculomotor measure), 1=questionable (ADHD sample but suitability of oculomotor measure to be discussed, open population with ADHD-like characteristics, comorbid samples, reviews with valuable information, rapid eye movements (REM) during sleep) and, 2=likely suitable (research studies with at least one group of individuals with ADHD, and oculomotor measures related to inhibitory control).
After abstract screening, we decided to exclude studies about REM sleep since these cannot
be used to index inhibitory oculomotor control as conceptualized in this study. The primary researcher screened full texts and decided whether these were suitable for inclusion. Again, a score from 0 to 2 was assigned to each record, as above.
A second researcher (SS) will double-check full texts and score them independently and blind
to the scores from the first researcher. Level of agreement will be assessed, and disagreement resolved through discussion with the leading member of the research project (UE). We will record the reasons for excluding studies. Researchers will not be blind to journal titles, study authors or institutions.

11c. Planned method of extracting data: Data extraction will be completed by YC and
confirmed independently in a subset of 10 studies by SS. If any information from the studies is incomplete or unclear we will contact the corresponding and/or other author(s) on the paper by email, three times over three weeks. If no response is received four weeks after the first email and eligibility cannot be determined, the study will be excluded.

12. Data items
For each selected study, information will be extracted on publication (names of authors, publication year, journal, language), sample characteristics (diagnostic status, sample size, average age, sex distribution), the type of criteria used to define ADHD (e.g., DSM-III, DSM-IV, DSM-5, ICD-10). When possible, we will extract the scores from the scales used to characterize ADHD and the severity of ADHD symptoms (inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity), and the medication status (ON/OFF, type of medication, dose).

13. Outcomes and prioritization
The outcome measures to be considered are enlisted below, each outcome is defined in Table 1 and Table 2 (Appendix A):

Primary outcomes (measures reported as inhibitory control parameters):
1. Direction errors (antisaccade tasks)
2. Saccades to distractors (oculomotor capture task)
3. Intrusive saccades (oculomotor capture task)
4. Anticipatory saccades (memory-guided saccade task)
5. Intrusive saccades (memory-guided saccade task)
6. Stop signal reaction time (saccadic countermanding task)
7. Intrusive saccades (prolonged fixation task)
8. Anticipatory saccades (smooth pursuit)

Secondary outcomes (measures related to timing and spatial parameters of oculomotor response):
1. Saccadic reaction time (mean, SD, CV) (visually-guided, memory-guided, antisaccade,
oculomotor capture)
2. Express saccades (visually-guided, memory-guided, antisaccade, oculomotor capture)
3. Saccadic gain (visually-guided, memory-guided, antisaccade, oculomotor capture)
4. Distance error / spatial accuracy (visually-guided, memory-guided, antisaccade, oculomotor capture)
5. Saccadic velocity (mean and peak velocity) (visually-guided, memory-guided, antisaccade,
oculomotor capture)
6. Fixation duration (prolonged fixation task)
7. Pursuit gain (smooth pursuit)
8. Catch-up saccades (smooth pursuit)
9. Back-up saccades (smooth pursuit)
10. Square jerk waves (smooth pursuit)

14. Risk of bias in individual studies
Papers selected for inclusion will be subjected to appraisal following the guidelines of the JBI
Critical Appraisal Checklist for Analytical Cross Sectional Studies, a tool designed by the Joanna Briggs Institute (https://reviewersmanual.joannabriggs.org/). This checklist allows to assess the methodological quality of individual studies and to determine the extent to which each study has addressed the possibility of bias in its design, conduct, and analysis (Moola et al., 2017). 

15. Data synthesis
15a. Criteria for data synthesis: We will analyze those outcomes (e.g. direction errors from
antisaccade task) that are reported in at least five different studies (k=5), to ensure we have enough data to proceed with statistical analyses. Means and standard deviations will be extracted from those oculomotor measures and we will calculate the standardized mean difference (Hedge’s g) if it is not already reported. When the mean and SD are not provided in a study, we will request them to the authors. If they do not reply within the defined time (Item 11c) or provide sufficient information, the study will be excluded. If the number of studies reporting each outcome is sufficient, we will conduct meta-analyses using a random-effects model for each outcome. Our main parameter will be the effect size representing the differences between ADHD participants and controls.
Measures will be combined and calculated using “metafor” package (Viechtbauer, 2010) for
R (version 3.6.1, http://www.r-project.org/).

15b. Planned analyses:
- Individual effect sizes for each outcome will be entered into a random-effects model to
compute an overall effect size.
- Summary effect sizes will be computed using a restricted maximum-likelihood estimator.
- Heterogeneity will be assessed in the studies by calculating the I2 value, which describes the percentage of total variation across studies that is explained by heterogeneity rather than chance (Higgins et al., 2003).

15c. Additional analyses: If heterogeneity explains a large amount of variance (I2> 75%), metaregression analyses will be conducted including age, sex, medication status, as factors to explore their influences as potential sources of variance. If needed, a subgroup analyses will be implemented depending on what factor or factors are found to be strong moderators.

15d. Alternative analyses: In the case quantitative analyses are not possible, or we found
qualitative information that is relevant for the meta-analysis, we will synthesize the information in the text and in tables to summarise the main characteristics of the included studies, and to explore the differences and relationships among the reported findings.

16. Planned assessment of meta-bias(es)
- Funnel plot of the selected studies will be used to inspect the symmetry of effect size distribution.
- Linear regression test for funnel plot asymmetry will be considered to test for publication
bias.
- In the case of significant publication bias, trim-and-fill analyses will be implemented.

17. Confidence in cumulative estimate
Given that the protocol is not designed to assess intervention effects or other clinical
implications, we consider this section not necessary.

SECTION 4: Additional information

Deviations from the plan: NA.

REFERENCES

11b. Process for selecting studies: YC conducted the first screening by reviewing the titles
and abstracts yielded by the search (abstract screening). A score ranging from 0 to 2 was assigned to each record as follows: 0=unsuitable (no ADHD sample, or no oculomotor measure), 1=questionable (ADHD sample but suitability of oculomotor measure to be discussed, open population with ADHD-like characteristics, comorbid samples, reviews with valuable information, rapid eye movements (REM) during sleep) and, 2=likely suitable (research studies with at least one group of individuals with ADHD, and oculomotor measures related to inhibitory control).
After abstract screening, we decided to exclude studies about REM sleep since these cannot
be used to index inhibitory oculomotor control as conceptualized in this study. The primary researcher screened full texts and decided whether these were suitable for inclusion. Again, a score from 0 to 2 was assigned to each record, as above.
A second researcher (SS) will double-check full texts and score them independently and blind
to the scores from the first researcher. Level of agreement will be assessed, and disagreement resolved through discussion with the leading member of the research project (UE). We will record the reasons for excluding studies. Researchers will not be blind to journal titles, study authors or institutions.

11c. Planned method of extracting data: Data extraction will be completed by YC and
confirmed independently in a subset of 10 studies by SS. If any information from the studies is incomplete or unclear we will contact the corresponding and/or other author(s) on the paper by email, three times over three weeks. If no response is received four weeks after the first email and eligibility cannot be determined, the study will be excluded.

12. Data items
For each selected study, information will be extracted on publication (names of authors, publication year, journal, language), sample characteristics (diagnostic status, sample size, average age, sex distribution), the type of criteria used to define ADHD (e.g., DSM-III, DSM-IV, DSM-5, ICD-10). When possible, we will extract the scores from the scales used to characterize ADHD and the severity of ADHD symptoms (inattention and hyperactivity-impulsivity), and the medication status (ON/OFF, type of medication, dose).

13. Outcomes and prioritization
The outcome measures to be considered are enlisted below, each outcome is defined in Table 1 and Table 2 (Appendix A):

Primary outcomes (measures reported as inhibitory control parameters):
1. Direction errors (antisaccade tasks)
2. Saccades to distractors (oculomotor capture task)
3. Intrusive saccades (oculomotor capture task)
4. Anticipatory saccades (memory-guided saccade task)
5. Intrusive saccades (memory-guided saccade task)
6. Stop signal reaction time (saccadic countermanding task)
7. Intrusive saccades (prolonged fixation task)
8. Anticipatory saccades (smooth pursuit)

Secondary outcomes (measures related to timing and spatial parameters of oculomotor response):
1. Saccadic reaction time (mean, SD, CV) (visually-guided, memory-guided, antisaccade,
oculomotor capture)
2. Express saccades (visually-guided, memory-guided, antisaccade, oculomotor capture)
3. Saccadic gain (visually-guided, memory-guided, antisaccade, oculomotor capture)
4. Distance error / spatial accuracy (visually-guided, memory-guided, antisaccade, oculomotor capture)
5. Saccadic velocity (mean and peak velocity) (visually-guided, memory-guided, antisaccade,
oculomotor capture)
6. Fixation duration (prolonged fixation task)
7. Pursuit gain (smooth pursuit)
8. Catch-up saccades (smooth pursuit)
9. Back-up saccades (smooth pursuit)
10. Square jerk waves (smooth pursuit)

14. Risk of bias in individual studies
Papers selected for inclusion will be subjected to appraisal following the guidelines of the JBI
Critical Appraisal Checklist for Analytical Cross Sectional Studies, a tool designed by the Joanna Briggs Institute (https://reviewersmanual.joannabriggs.org/). This checklist allows to assess the methodological quality of individual studies and to determine the extent to which each study has addressed the possibility of bias in its design, conduct, and analysis (Moola et al., 2017). 

15. Data synthesis
15a. Criteria for data synthesis: We will analyze those outcomes (e.g. direction errors from
antisaccade task) that are reported in at least five different studies (k=5), to ensure we have enough data to proceed with statistical analyses. Means and standard deviations will be extracted from those oculomotor measures and we will calculate the standardized mean difference (Hedge’s g) if it is not already reported. When the mean and SD are not provided in a study, we will request them to the authors. If they do not reply within the defined time (Item 11c) or provide sufficient information, the study will be excluded. If the number of studies reporting each outcome is sufficient, we will conduct meta-analyses using a random-effects model for each outcome. Our main parameter will be the effect size representing the differences between ADHD participants and controls.
Measures will be combined and calculated using “metafor” package (Viechtbauer, 2010) for
R (version 3.6.1, http://www.r-project.org/).

15b. Planned analyses:
- Individual effect sizes for each outcome will be entered into a random-effects model to
compute an overall effect size.
- Summary effect sizes will be computed using a restricted maximum-likelihood estimator.
- Heterogeneity will be assessed in the studies by calculating the I2 value, which describes the percentage of total variation across studies that is explained by heterogeneity rather than chance (Higgins et al., 2003).

15c. Additional analyses: If heterogeneity explains a large amount of variance (I2> 75%), metaregression analyses will be conducted including age, sex, medication status, as factors to explore their influences as potential sources of variance. If needed, a subgroup analyses will be implemented depending on what factor or factors are found to be strong moderators.

15d. Alternative analyses: In the case quantitative analyses are not possible, or we found
qualitative information that is relevant for the meta-analysis, we will synthesize the information in the text and in tables to summarise the main characteristics of the included studies, and to explore the differences and relationships among the reported findings.

16. Planned assessment of meta-bias(es)
- Funnel plot of the selected studies will be used to inspect the symmetry of effect size distribution.
- Linear regression test for funnel plot asymmetry will be considered to test for publication
bias.
- In the case of significant publication bias, trim-and-fill analyses will be implemented.

17. Confidence in cumulative estimate
Given that the protocol is not designed to assess intervention effects or other clinical
implications, we consider this section not necessary.

SECTION 4: Additional information

Deviations from the plan: NA.

question5a.value: The internet has revolutionized the way in which we consume news, and this migration from print to digital has fundamentally reshaped the economic structure of the media industry. Over a quarter of newspaper revenue now comes from digital advertising, with this share growing every year (Pew Research Centre, 2018). This puts pressure on newspapers to increase traffic to their websites in order to maximize revenues: this can be done through use of clickbait. Clickbait is a term used to describe articles and headlines written in a dramatic manner in order to grab users’ attention and get them to click onto and read additional content. The headline is made to seem exciting, but the content of the article may not always deliver on the promise of the headline. Clickbait uses our attention system to generate curiosity and cognitive arousal, causing us to engage more with content. Clickbait headlines results in negative effects on perceived source credibility (Hurst, 2016), and fake news stories with clickbait headlines were viewed 38 million times on Facebook prior to the 2016 US presidential election (Allcott & Gentzkow, 2017). The role of clickbait in the attention economy suggests that newspapers who have incentives to increase ad revenue will increase clickbait, and that clickbait will generally increase over time.

attributes.title: A systematic review and Meta-analysis of the Unified Protocol RCTs

summary.value: The Unified Protocol (UP) is a transdiagnostic CBT that targets the shared emotional disorder mechanisms of Neuroticism/Negative Affectivity (N/NA). This meta-analysis is the first to examine whether, for adults diagnosed with emotional disorders, the UP was more efficacious than comparators for the improvements in anxiety, depression, and N/NA. Extensive database searches were narrowed to eighteen UP randomized control trials (RCTs). Meta-analyses of RCT data showed the UP outperformed comparators with effect sizes (pre- to post-treatment) that were large for anxiety and depression and moderate for N/NA, these were stable at short-term follow-up. For anxiety and depressive outcomes the UP surpassed waitlist control and treatment-as-usual comparators and was equivalent to traditional CBT. Moderators for depressive outcomes were non-inferiority studies and for anxiety outcomes the protocol language. These results suggest the UP is efficacious for single and co-occurring emotional disorders. Higher quality RCTs can provide more decisive support for this psychotherapy’s efficacy. The entire summary and protocol description of this systematic review and meta-analysis is in the attached file.
